bibl.title: Letter from Wilbur A. Sawyer to Albert E. Truby, February 4, 1936

div1.p: Sawyer thanks Truby for responding to his letter, and is pleased with Truby's opinion regarding Dean.

div1.head: Letter from Wilbur A. Sawyer to Albert E. Truby, February 4, 1936

CABLE ADDRESS: ROCKFOUND, NEW YORK
February 4, 1936
Dear General Truby:
div1.p:
It was good of you to write me so fully in
your letter of January 27 in answer to my questions regarding
Dr. Agramonte's monkey experiment and the reliability of the
play “Yellowjack.” I do not believe that Reed or Carroll
published the work on animals. Agramonte did not do so until
several years afterward. He does give particulars regarding
the experiment, however, and it seems quite reasonable that
tests would have been made on animals by the Commission when
infectious material was so readily available.

I am very much pleased to know that there
is no special evidence that Dean was not a bona fide volunteer
in the mosquito experiments. I had always assumed that the
implication in the play “Yellowjack” that Dean was tricked was
not correct and I am now better able to contradict this implica-
tion in reply to inquiries.

Thanking you again for your trouble to ans-
wer my questions, I am
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, W A Sawyer General Albert E. Truby
3559 Jackson Street
San Francisco, California
